title.narrative: IOM CREST Ethical Recruitment of Migrant Workers
IOM CREST Etisk rekrytering av migrantarbetare

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 IOM:s femåriga projekt, "Enhancing Corporate Responsibility in Eliminating Slavery and Trafficking in Asia (CREST Project)", syftar till att förbättra villkoren för migrantarbetare i Asien genom att stärka kapaciteten hos privatsektoraktörer inom leverantörskedjor i Asien att rekrytera och anställa enligt internationella principer för etisk rekrytering. Projektet ämnar förhindra den sårbara situation som framförallt många kvinnor hamnar i genom arbetsmigration, såsom skuldsättning till följd av dyra rekryteringsavgifter, avsaknad av rätt till exempelvis sjukvård i destinationslandet och svaga rättigheter gentemot arbetsgivaren. Då rekryteringsfirmor spelar en viktig roll kommer IOM att särskilt kartlägga och utbilda dessa i syfte att de ska efterleva internationella principer för etisk rekrytering. En av kärnprinciperna är att rekryteringskostnaden ska bäras av det företag som i slutänden anställer och inte av arbetstagaren som migrerar. Internationella företag som köper från asiatiska leverantörer förväntas engageras i projektet och bidra med resurser till att stärka kapaciteten hos sina underleverantörer. Målet är att få till stånd etiskt hållbara rekryteringsprocesser som väntas leda till att migrerande kvinnor och män har större tillgång till säkra rekryteringskanaler där de inte råkar ut för exploatering, kränkningar eller hamnar i ekonomisk skuld när de flyttar för att arbeta på annan ort.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 IOM’s five year project, "Enhancing Corporate Responsibility in Eliminating Slavery and Trafficking in Asia (CREST Project)", aims to improve the conditions for migrant workers in Asia by strengthening the capacity of private sector actors’ value chains in Asia, to recruit and hire in accordance with international praxis for ethical recruitment. The project aims to hinder the vulnerable situation that many women face in labour migration, such as indebtedness due to high recruitment fees, lack of right to healthcare in the country of destination and weak rights in relation to the employer. As the recruitment firms have an important role, IOM will map and train these to adhere to international principles for ethical recruitment. One of the core principles is that the recruitment fee shall be absorbed by the company that in the end employs and not borne by the migrant worker. International companies that source from Asian suppliers are expected to be engaged in the project and contribute with resources to strengthen the capacity of its suppliers. The aim is to establish ethical recruitment practices that are expected to lead to that more migrating women and men have better access to safe recruitment channels and are not exposed to exploitation, violation or indebted when moving to seek work at another destination.

To better enable private sector and regional actors to protect the human and labour rights of women and men migrant workers in Asia, in key industries and supply chains.
Indicators to follow up the intervention objective include: the number of employers that have eliminated worker-paid recruitment fees in their supply chains, the number of migrant workers accessing ethical recruitment channels in accordance with the IRIS Standard, and whether industry groups and private-public partnerships has contributed to rights-based policy making in relation to international labour mobility in Asia.

description.narrative: Key results from the IOM-CREST Asia programme are summarised below. For full information, please refer to the annual COP in January 2021. -At present, IOM-CREST has gained 20+ private sector partnerships approximate to USD 6.5m, which is beyond the original expected target of private sector contribution to the programme. With these partnerships, the activities could potentially 140,420 migrant workers employed within these supply chains. -7 Supply chain mapping across 10 countries for a high-risk industry (labour intensive sector) which are apparel and footwear, agriculture (plantation), electronic, retails and home furniture. The supply chain mapping goes deeper than normal social audits/ compliance check since the assessment is done based on the migration process and experiences of low-skilled migrant workers. Through the 7 supply mapping, 550+ migrant workers, 11 brands, 157 suppliers, 103 labour recruiters and 14 sub-agents were interviewed. -In 2020, the programme was successful in delivering the first cross-border labour supply chain mapping in the palm oil sector through the partnership with Earthworm Foundation. -Customised policies and procedures in the promotion of migrant workers' rights are developed for 5 brands. 54 training sessions delivered to 914 participants -7 multi-stakeholder consultations in 7 countries with 2,763 participants -IOM-CREST works closely with the businesses and their suppliers to strengthenhuman rights due diligence to support the implementation of ethical recruitmentand improving access to remedy. Technical inputs and training were provided to amultinational electronics company to develop and adopt a protocol for reimbursement of excessive recruitment fees and costs to the current migrant workforce. Importantly, the guideline to remedy for employers was launched in June 2021. -Although IOM-CREST focuses at the role of the business sector in upholding the rights of migrant labour, the programme realises the necessity of engaging with the right holder i.e. migrant workers as their key partner. In 2020, the programme successfully launched the strategic partnership with regional migrant labours network, Migrant Forum Asia (MFA). The objective of the partnership is to strengthen the capacity of civil society to engage with the private sector on protection of migrant workers which is currently lacking. Two gender briefs were produced and circulated with CREST partners includingAddressing Women Migrant Worker Vulnerabilities in International Supply Chains and Gender info sheet, to improve business understanding on gender dimensions of labour exploitation in the context of labour migration into international business supply chains. Through direct partnerships with multinational enterprises, IOM advocates for a gender-sensitive approach and to incorporate gender-sensitive awareness, questions and solutions to the tools, guidance, and policies that IOM has generated. The operation of IOM-CREST is well in line with the trend of Business and Human Rights in the region. IOM-CREST and UNDP B+HR has started the coordination in 2019 in which the former was invited to participate in the BHR Forum Asia. In June 2021, IOM became one of the co-organisers of BHR Forum Asia. This development shows increased collaboration between the two initiatives. Additionally given the launch of the NAP by Thailand and Japan as well as the current development of the NAP process in some countries in this region, there is strategic opportunity for the programme to deepen its engagement and leverage its relevance in the region. A profile of IOM-CREST is incrementally increasing amongst a wider group ofactors and stakeholders. Although the programme's focus is specific to the collaboration with the private sector, the programme has been also consulted for inputs to the government ministries, policy makers, and other UN agencies in relevant field. For example, the capacity building was provided to SMEs in Malaysia as per the request of Ministry of International Trade and Industries and the technical input was fed into the development National Action Plan on Responsible Business Conduct as per the request of the Vietnamese Government. Potential institutionalisation of CREST knowledge into a wider IOM framework. The initial discussion at wider IOM divisions identified the possibility of increasing its engagement with private sector on labour supply chain integrity and migrant worker protection. A feasibility study, financed by IOM’s Migration Resource Allocation Committee (MIRAC), an internal funding mechanism, has started to explore and support a roll-out of the CREST methodology and tools to contribute to IOM´s widerefforts on pertaining to engagement with the private sector partners. IOM-CREST contributes to the learning and testing ground for the role ofbusiness in sustainable development. The programme has a wealth of knowledge to share with wider audiences for joint-learning, areas for improvement and potential synergies with other actors. For example, the joint online learning session between Sida and IOM-CREST was held in May 2020 to share the experiences, key lessons and observations from the programme implementation including in the context of the Covid-19. The session was attended by the Sida and IOM staff from field office and the HQ.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
